messageBody:
Jan,

That is exactly what we do however, not all classes in the test package are
tests. There are Mocks, utility classes etc.. As well as Test classes that
are annotated with Test-NG. However, junit's ant task isn't smart enough to
distinguish the difference. I find that pretty horrible! What is the use of
a @Test annotation if it isn't used?? pretty crazy. Thanks for the help
though.

On 8/21/07, j_cumps <j_cumps@...> wrote:
>
> Gommo,
>
> > Is there any way out of the box to make Junit just run the tests
> that use
> > org.junit.Test annoations ??
>
> What we (and several open source projects) typically do when using
> JUnit and Ant is:
> place your source files in a folder called src
> place your test classes in a folder called tst
>
> When running the junit ant task, let it look in the location of your
> test classes for tests it has to run.
>
> Example:
>
> sources:
> src/com/myproject/Foo.java
> src/com/myproject/Bar.java
>
> test sources:
> tst/com/myproject/FooTest.java
> tst/com/myproject/BarTest.java
>
> compile sources to destination build/bin, and tests to destination
> build/tst
>
> in build.xml:
>
> <property name="build.dir" value="build"/>
>
> <!-- Testing Classpath -->
> <path id="junit.classpath">
> <pathelement location="${junit.jar}"/>
> <pathelement location="${build.dir}/src"/>
> <pathelement location="${build.dir}/tst"/>
> </path>
>
> compilation part:
> ...
>
> <target name="build" depends....">
> <mkdir dir="${build.dir}/src"/>
> <javac srcdir="src"
> destdir="${build.dir}/src">
> </javac>
> <mkdir dir="${build.dir}/tst"/>
> <javac srcdir="tst"
> destdir="${build.dir}/tst" classpathref="junit.classpath"
> debug="true">
> </javac>
> </target>
>
> ...
>
> test part will only pick up your test classes in the tst subdir, and
> their class name has to contain Test in it.
>
> <target name="test">
>
> <junit ...>
> <formatter type="brief" usefile="false"/>
> <classpath refid="junit.classpath"/>
>
> <batchtest ...>
> <fileset dir="tst">
> <include name="**/*Test*.java"/>
> </fileset>
> </batchtest>
> </junit>
>
>
> </target>
>
> Regards, Jan
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com <junit%40yahoogroups.com>, "David Saff"
> <saff@...> wrote:
> >
> > Gommo,
> >
> > I am not an expert user of the junit ant task--I hope that someone
> > else on this list is, and can provide more insight. You might want
> to
> > look at the Johannes' Links ClasspathSuite runner:
> >
> > http://johanneslink.net/cpsuite.html
> >
> > Using this, you'd point ant at a single suite class, which would
> > itself indicate the directory in which to search for tests. I've
> > found cpsuite remarkably fast for small-to-medium projects, but
> can't
> > say how it scales to large or very large projects. Thanks,
> >
> > David Saff
> >
> > On 8/19/07, gommo <colin.goudie@...> wrote:
> > >
> > > I've been using TestNG for more unit and integration tests.
> However, I've
> > > found that JUnit 4 and its eclipse plugin works faster and nicer.
> So I've
> > > decided change all my unit tests to JUnit.
> > >
> > > I have a runUnitTests ant target that is used to run (previously)
> the
> > > test-ng tests that are marked as "UnitTests"
> > >
> > > As a start, I have changed this ant target to run all tests in my
> tests
> > > target directory (i.e. using **/*.class)
> > >
> > > What I thought would happen was that JUnit would look at these
> classes, find
> > > the ones that are marked with the JUnit 4 @Test annotation and
> run them.
> > >
> > > What I'm finding however is that it is attempting to run EVERY
> class in that
> > > folder as a test and they are either Test-NG tests or just other
> utility
> > > classes. As a result, JUnit is throwing errors
> > >
> > > e.g.
> > > Running au.tributech.tuxedo.beans.entity.PermissionTest$1
> > > [junit] Tests run: 2, Failures: 0, Errors: 2, Time elapsed:
> 0.017 sec
> > > [junit] Test
> au.tributech.tuxedo.beans.entity.PermissionTest$1 FAILED
> > > [junit] Running
> > >
> au.tributech.tuxedo.beans.entity.PermissionTest$PermissionDescendant
> > > [junit] Tests run: 2, Failures: 0, Errors: 2, Time elapsed:
> 0.018 sec
> > > [junit] Test
> > >
> au.tributech.tuxedo.beans.entity.PermissionTest$PermissionDescendant
> FAILED
> > >
> > > Is there any way out of the box to make Junit just run the tests
> that use
> > > org.junit.Test annoations ??
> > >
> > > What I have got working (but its slow) is to write a custom ANT
> selector.
> > > <batchtest fork="yes" todir="${test.report.dir}">
> > > <fileset dir="${test.fixtures.dir}" includes="**/*.class">
> > > <custom classname="au.tributech.ant.JUnit4Selector"
> > > classpathref="project.test.run.classpath"/>
> > > </fileset>
> > > </batchtest>
> > >
> > > The JUnit4Selector class I wrote simply reads in each file
> processed and
> > > uses ASM-3.0 to look for JUnit4 annotations (@Test, @RunsWith
> etc..). If
> > > they exist it processes that file otherwise skips it.
> > >
> > > This works but it is pretty slow and I can see it being painfully
> slow when
> > > there are hundreds of unit tests.
> > >
> > > Surely I'm missing something here and JUnit's ANT task is smarter
> than what
> > > it is appearing. I don't want to have to specify EVERY unit test
> when I add
> > > them. That is just a maintenance nightmare.
> > >
> > > Thanks for any pointers
